abstract.text: Provides native iOS access to the Stytch SDK methods for ultimate flexibility.

inlineContent.text: The iOS SDK provides methods that communicate directly with the Stytch API. These help you get up and running with Stytch faster by removing the need to create endpoints on your backend to make requests to
In addition to StytchCore we have a seperate dependency for our pre built UI framework,
, which provides a out of the box solution for using Stytch.
You’ll interact with Stytch via the
(B2B apps), depending on your use case. Supported Stytch products are accessed via nested static variables on the client, e.g.
, where you can access the underlying methods, e.g.

abstract.text: The SDK allows you to view the current member’s information, such as fetching (or viewing the most recent cached version) of the current member.
The interface which a data type must conform to for all underlying data in
responses.
An empty type to allow encoding/decoding the absence of a value within various generic Codable types.
The response type for user-management calls.

The SDK allows you to manage the current user’s information, such as fetching the user, viewing the most recent cached version of the user, or deleting existing authentication factors associated with this user.
The RBAC Policy document that contains all defined Roles and Resources – which are managed in the Dashboard (https://stytch.com/dashboard/rbac).
Read more about these entities and how they work in our RBAC overview (https://stytch.com/docs/b2b/guides/rbac/overview).

calls.

Provides native iOS access to the Stytch SDK methods for ultimate flexibility.
Error class representing an error within the Stytch SDK.

Session endpoint and validates that the session issued to the user is still valid, returning both an opaque sessionToken and sessionJwt for this session. The sessionJwt will have a fixed lifetime of five minutes regardless of the underlying session duration, though it will be refreshed automatically in the background after a successful authentication.
Error class representing an error within the Stytch API.
Authenticate a member with their email address and password. This method verifies that the member has a password currently set, and that the entered password is correct.
Evaluates all permissions granted to the logged-in member.
Returns a Map<RoleId, Map<Action, Boolean>> response indicating the member’s permissions.
Each boolean will be
if the member can perform the action,
otherwise.
The interface which a data type must conform to for all discovery flows that return a non optional intermediate session token
A generic protocol to define operand types generating the JSON needed for a search query.
OAuth allows you to leverage outside identity providers, for which your users may already have an account, to verify their identity. This is a low-friction method your users will be familiar with.
The concrete response type for B2B MFA
calls.
Initiates the OAuth flow by using the included parameters to start a Sign In With Apple request. If the authentication is successful this method will return a new session object.
Biometric authentication enables your users to leverage their devices’ built-in biometric authenticators such as FaceID and TouchID for quick and seamless login experiences.
Rotate the recovery codes for an authenticated member
A Role is a named collection of permissions that links actions to a Resource.
Roles are assigned to Members, either explicitly by direct assignment or implicitly by matching attributes or conditions, which grants them permissions.
Role assignment can be programmatically managed through certain Stytch API endpoints.
Refer to this guide for details on controls for delegating Roles to Members (https://stytch.com/docs/b2b/guides/rbac/role-assignment).
All Roles are stored in your Project’s RBAC Policy. You can create, manage, and assign Roles in the Dashboard (https://stytch.com/dashboard).
Check out the RBAC overview to learn more about Stytch’s RBAC permissioning model (https://stytch.com/docs/b2b/guides/rbac/overview).
The SDK provides methods that can be used to authenticate a user via their crypto wallet.
The entrypoint for all Stytch B2B-related interaction.
Magic links can be sent via email and allow for a quick and seamless login experience.
Search for an organization by its slug
Fetches the most up-to-date version of the current user.
Error class representing a schema error within the Stytch API.

Session endpoint and validates that the session issued to the user is still valid, returning both an opaque sessionToken and sessionJwt for this session. The sessionJwt will have a fixed lifetime of five minutes regardless of the underlying session duration, though it will be refreshed automatically in the background after a successful authentication.
Magic links can be sent via email and allow for a quick and seamless login experience.
This method allows you to check whether the member’s provided password is valid, and to provide feedback to the member on how to increase the strength of their password.

responses.
The SDK provides the ability to integrate with the natively-supported Sign In With Apple flow.
The HTTP status code of the request.
A type defining a session; including information about its validity, expiry, factors associated with this session, and more.

endpoint. Requests an email magic link for a user to log in or create an account depending on the presence and/or status of an existing account.

Session endpoint and revokes the user’s current session. This method should be used to log out a user. A successful revocation will terminate session-refresh polling.
Returns the most-recent cached copy of the user object, if it has already been fetched via another method, else nil.
A list of permissions that link a Resource to a list of actions.

When a valid/active session exists, this method will add a biometric registration for the current user. The user will later be able to start a new session with biometrics or use biometrics as an additional authentication factor.
Initiates a password reset for the email address provided. This will trigger an email to be sent to the address, containing a magic link that will allow them to set a new password and authenticate.
A generic type which encompasses the
and
, along with dynamic member accessors for the wrapped type.
Stytch supports creating, storing, and authenticating passwords, as well as support for account recovery (password reset) and account deduplication with passwordless login methods.
Our implementation of passwords has built-in breach detection powered by
on both sign-up and login, to prevent the use of compromised credentials and uses configurable strength requirements (either Dropbox’s
or adjustable LUDS) to guide members towards creating passwords that are easy for humans to remember but difficult for computers to crack.
The SDK allows you to view the member’s current organization information, such as fetching (or viewing the most recent cached version) of the current organziation.
Deletes, by id, an existing authentication factor associated with the current user.
Stytch supports creating, storing, and authenticating password based users, as well as support for account recovery (password reset) and account deduplication with passwordless login methods.
Our implementation of passwords has built-in breach detection powered by
on both sign-up and login, to prevent the use of compromised credentials and uses Dropbox’s
strength requirements to guide users towards creating passwords that are easy for humans to remember but difficult for computers to crack.
Consume a recovery code for a member
Wraps Stytch’s email magic link
endpoint. Requests an email magic link for a member to log in or signup depending on the presence and/or status of an existing account.
A type representing the different kinds of session tokens available.
Wraps Stytch’s Crypto wallet
endpoint. Call this method to load the challenge data. Pass this challenge to your user’s wallet for signing.
Authenticate a user with their email address and password. This method verifies that the user has a password currently set, and that the entered password is correct.
Returns the most-recent cached copy of the member object, if it has already been fetched via another method, else nil.
Used to determine which language to use when sending the user this delivery method. Parameter is a IETF BCP 47 language tag, e.g. “en”.
https://www.w3.org/International/articles/language-tags/
A Resource is an entity with an associated list of actions.
The actions list enumerates all the valid operations that can be performed upon the Resource.
All Resources are stored in your Project’s RBAC Policy. You can create and manage Resources in the Dashboard (https://stytch.com/dashboard).
Check out the RBAC overview to learn more about Stytch’s RBAC permissioning model (https://stytch.com/docs/b2b/guides/rbac/overview).
A generic asynchronous callback returning a
A simple, generic, wrapper type which combines two values and provides dynamic-member-access to the underlying wrapped values.
Wraps Stytch’s
endpoint. Call this method to authenticate a recovery code for a TOTP instance.
A type which describes an factor used to authenticate a session.
E.g. An email which was used to log in, or a phone which was used
via SMS as an OTP second factor.
The Send Discovery Email method wraps the
API endpoint.
Reset the member’s password and authenticate them. This endpoint checks that the session is valid and hasn’t expired or been revoked.
Wraps the OTP
API endpoint which validates the one-time code passed in. If this method succeeds, the user will be logged in, granted an active session, and the session cookies will be minted and stored in
The Discovery product lets End Users discover and log in to Organizations they are a Member of, invited to, or eligible to join.
Unlike our other B2B products, Discovery allows End Users to authenticate without specifying an Organization in advance. This is done via a
flow. After an End User is
, an Intermediate Session is returned along with a list of associated Organizations.
The End User can then authenticate to the desired Organization by passing the Intermediate Session and
. End users can even create a new Organization instead of joining or logging in to an existing one.
The underlying data for B2B
calls.
This method allows you to check whether or not the user’s provided password is valid, and to provide feedback to the user on how to increase the strength of their password.
A type defining an organization member, including information about their name, status, authentication factors, and more.

Time-based One-time Passcodes (TOTPs) are one-time passcodes that are generated based on a shared secret and the current time. TOTPs are also often referred to as Authenticator Apps and are a common form of secondary authentication. Creating a Stytch instance of a TOTP for a User creates a shared secret. This secret is shared by Stytch with the end user’s authenticator application of choice (e.g. Google Authenticator). The authenticator app can then generate TOTPs that are valid for a specific amount of time (generally 30 seconds). The end user inputs the TOTP and the developer can use the authenticate method to verify that the TOTP is valid. To call these methods, TOTPs must be enabled in the
of the Stytch dashboard.
StytchObjectInfo provides a generic way to unify the publishing of Stytch object types.
If there is an object to publish you will get
, which will publish the object
and the date is was last validated at. The receiver of the event if the object is within their time tolerance for use.
If there is no object to publish you will get
. So the publisher will never have to publish a nil value.
Determines whether the logged-in member is allowed to perform the specified action on the specified resource.
Returns
if the member can perform the action,
otherwise.
Reset the member’s password and authenticate them. This endpoint checks that the magic link token is valid, hasn’t expired, or already been used.
A type defining a user; including information about their name, status, the auth factors associated with them, and more.
Represents the interface of responses for B2B
calls.
The entrypoint for all Stytch-related interaction.
Wraps Stytch’s email magic link
endpoint. Requests an email magic link for an existing user to log in or attach the included email factor to their current account.
Initiates a password reset for the email address provided. This will trigger an email to be sent to the address, containing a magic link that will allow them to set a new password and authenticate.
Wraps Stytch’s OTP
, and
endpoints. Requests a one-time passcode for an existing user to log in or attach the included factor to their current account.
Fetches the most up-to-date version of the current organization.

One-time passcodes can be sent via email, phone number, or WhatsApp. One-time passcodes allow for a quick and seamless login experience on their own, or can layer on top of another login product like Email magic links to provide extra security as a multi-factor authentication (MFA) method.
Base class representing an error within the Stytch ecosystem.
The dedicated parameters type for the
call.
A type defining a member’s session; including information about its validity, expiry, factors associated with this session, and more.
Represents one of two kinds of tokens used to represent a session (see
, for more info.) These tokens are used to authenticate the current user/member.

The SDK may be used to check whether a user has a cached session, view the current session, refresh the session, and revoke the session. To authenticate a session on your backend, you must use either the Stytch API or a Stytch server-side library.

: - After a successful authentication, the session will be automatically refreshed in the background to ensure the sessionJwt remains valid (it expires after 5 minutes.) Session polling will be stopped after a session is revoked or after an unauthenticated error response is received.
The interface which a data type must conform to for all underlying data in B2B
responses.
Error class representing when the Stytch SDK cannot reach the Stytch API.

endpoint. If the
is not passed in and there is a current Member Session, the SDK will call the endpoint with the session token.
Represents the interface of responses for B2B MFA
calls.

Represents whether a deeplink was able to be handled
Session-related information when appropriate.

calls.

endpoint. Call this method to create a new TOTP instance for a user. The user can use the authenticator application of their choice to scan the QR code or enter the secret.

Session endpoint and revokes the user’s current session. This method should be used to log out a user. A successful revocation will terminate session-refresh polling.

calls.
Create a new user with a password and an authenticated session for the user if requested. If a user with this email already exists in the project, an error will be returned.
Wraps Stytch’s
endpoint. Call this method to authenticate a TOTP code entered by a user.

The SDK may be used to check whether a user has a cached session, view the current session, refresh the session, and revoke the session. To authenticate a session on your backend, you must use either the Stytch API or a Stytch server-side library.

: - After a successful authentication, the session will be automatically refreshed in the background to ensure the sessionJwt remains valid (it expires after 5 minutes.) Session polling will be stopped after a session is revoked or after an unauthenticated error response is received.
Wraps Stytch’s Crypto wallet
endpoint. Call this method after the user signs the challenge to validate the signature.
The underlying data for B2B MFA
calls.

Reset the user’s password and authenticate them. This endpoint checks that the magic link token is valid, hasn’t expired, or already been used – and can optionally require additional security settings, such as the IP address and user agent matching the initial reset request.
Returns the most-recent cached copy of the organization object, if it has already been fetched via another method, else nil.
Authenticate a member given a token. This endpoint verifies that the memeber completed the SSO Authentication flow by
verifying that the token is valid and hasn’t expired.

endpoints. Requests a one-time passcode for a user to log in or create an account depending on the presence and/or status current account.

If a valid biometric registration exists, this method confirms the current device owner via the device’s built-in biometric reader and returns an updated session object by either starting a new session or adding a the biometric factor to an existing session.

endpoint. Call this method to retrieve the recovery codes for a TOTP instance tied to a user. Note: If a user has enrolled another MFA method, this method will require MFA. See the
section for more details.

Single-Sign On (SSO) refers to the ability for a user to use a single identity to authenticate and gain access to
multiple apps and service. In the case of B2B, it generally refers for the ability to use a workplace identity
managed by their company. Read our
for more information
about SSO.

API endpoint which validates the magic link token passed in.
